results.title: Hutt City Libraries
results.description: Hutt City Libraries is made up of eight local libraries and two Clubhouses based in Hutt City which provide access to print and digital books, newspapers, magazines, DVDs, and CDs. Many online resources are accessible for free for borrowers with a Library Card.
results.content: Hutt City Libraries is made up of eight local libraries and two Clubhouses based in Hutt City which provide access to print and digital books, newspapers, magazines, DVDs, and CDs.   Many online resources are accessible for free for borrowers with a Library Card.  These include Generosity NZ for funding applications, Anestry.com and Findmypast for family history research, Road to IELTS for English language practice, Beamafilm for streaming movies and documentaries and Story Box Library for children.  Hutt City Libraries run events for all ages including storytime and book groups, author and science talks, fun events for tamariki and their whānau, school holiday activities, computer classes, and JP clinics.  See website for more information or talk with their staff.
results.htmlcontent:
Hutt City Libraries is made up of eight local libraries and two Clubhouses based in Hutt City which provide access to print and digital books, newspapers, magazines, DVDs, and CDs.

Many online resources are accessible for free for borrowers with a Library Card.  These include Generosity NZ for funding applications, Anestry.com and Findmypast for family history research, Road to IELTS for English language practice, Beamafilm for streaming movies and documentaries and Story Box Library for children.

Hutt City Libraries run events for all ages including storytime and book groups, author and science talks, fun events for tamariki and their whānau, school holiday activities, computer classes, and JP clinics.

See website for more information or talk with their staff.

results.title: Hutt Minoh Friendship House
results.description: A Japanese cultural centre in Normandale, Lower Hutt, created from the sister city relationship between Lower Hutt and Minoh, Osaka, Japan. It is administered by the Hutt Minoh House Friendship Trust. Offers classes in Japanese culture and holds public events each year. The Hutt Minoh Friendship Club is for people interested in learning more about Japanese culture.
results.content: A Japanese cultural centre in Normandale, Lower Hutt, created from the sister city relationship between Lower Hutt and Minoh, Osaka, Japan.  It is administered by the Hutt Minoh House Friendship Trust. Offers classes in Japanese culture and holds public events each year.  The Hutt Minoh Friendship Club is for people interested in learning more about Japanese culture.  The House in Normandale is available for small conferences and private functions - bookings through Hutt City Council 570 6666.   Facebook page  - https://www.facebook.com/huttminoh/

results.title: Seido Karate Lower Hutt
results.description: Seido Karate Lower Hutt Dojo is a family values oriented dojo. The Seido Juku style of Karate was founded on three underlying principles: Love, Respect and Obedience. These principles are adhered to during training and form the basis of the dojo’s strong and encouraging atmosphere during classes.  Open to anyone over 4 years of age.  The training itself is “physical” and “challenging”.

results.title: Hutt Multicultural Council Inc
results.description: Hutt Multicultural Council promotes ethnic diversity in Lower Hutt. The Council supports migrants, refugees and overseas students through multicultural events, workshops, and networking.  Meets on 1st Thursday each month and new members are always welcome.  Email the secretary for details of meeting place. A charitable entity, HMC is affiliated to Multicultural NZ.  Hutt Multicultural Council organises the annual Multifest in Lower Hutt to celebrate diversity in this city.

Can take up to 50 children.

results.title: Hutt Valley Community Dance
results.description: A group of dance enthusiasts who hold regular dances at Chilton Saint James School Hall, Waterloo Road, Lower Hutt. The group also compiles an annual programme of these and similar dances throughout the Wellington region.

results.title: Crows Feet Dance Collective
results.description: Crows Feet Dance Collective has grown from a little group of four dancers to four separate groups - in Wellington, Lower Hutt, Kapiti and Palmerson North - with over forty dancers. A new programme of contemporary dance is performed every year.  Eligibility: Women aged over 35 yrs Fee structure: $20 per session (Wellington) or $15 per session (Hutt, Kapiti and Palmerston North). Intake process: Previous experience is not necessary

results.title: Mary Rodgers Dance Academy
results.description: Mary Rodgers Dance Academy provides dance lessons in Lower Hutt. They offer ballet, American jazz and pilates for children of all ages and abilities. They have two purpose-built studios. Royal Academy of Dance syllabus is taught to ballet students and examinations are offered, but not compulsory. This syllabus focuses on traditional classical ballet technique which provides a strong foundation for all other dance forms. New students can enrol at any time during the year.
results.content: Mary Rodgers Dance Academy provides dance lessons in Lower Hutt. They offer ballet, American jazz and pilates for children of all ages and abilities. They have two purpose-built studios.  Royal Academy of Dance syllabus is taught to ballet students and examinations are offered, but not compulsory.  This syllabus focuses on traditional classical ballet technique which provides a strong foundation for all other dance forms.  New students can enrol at any time during the year.  A registration form is on the website.  Prospective students can visit a class before committing to ongoing tuition.  Teachers are Royal Academy Registered.  the Academy has a purpose-built Pilates Equipment Studio available for private tuition for dance students.

results.title: New Zealand Kyudo Federation (NZKF)
results.description: There are dojos in:- Panmure, Auckland, Palmerston North, Lower Hutt, Wellington New Brighton, Christchurch.  Each dojo leader is a graded person with appropriate experience to teach kyudo safely. If interested in participating contact the dojo nearest you. Affiliations:- the All Nippon Kyudo Federation (ANKF) and the International Kyudo Federation (IKYF).
results.content: Promotes the practice and teaching of traditional Kyudo - the art of the Japanese bow - in New Zealand. Assists local groups in developing kyudo in both North and South Islands. Organises annual seminars for its members, (usually held in Auckland), members can also participate in international seminars held in Japan, and may take examinations for dan-ranking.  There are dojos in:-  Panmure, Auckland,  Palmerston North,  Lower Hutt, Wellington New Brighton, Christchurch.  Each dojo leader is a graded person with appropriate experience to teach kyudo safely. If interested in participating contact the dojo nearest you.  Affiliations:- the All Nippon Kyudo Federation (ANKF) and the International Kyudo Federation (IKYF).
results.htmlcontent:
Promotes the practice and teaching of traditional Kyudo - the art of the Japanese bow - in New Zealand. Assists local groups in developing kyudo in both North and South Islands. Organises annual seminars for its members, (usually held in Auckland), members can also participate in international seminars held in Japan, and may take examinations for dan-ranking.

There are dojos in:-

  • Panmure, Auckland,
  • Palmerston North,
  • Lower Hutt, Wellington
  • New Brighton, Christchurch. 

Each dojo leader is a graded person with appropriate experience to teach kyudo safely. If interested in participating contact the dojo nearest you.

Affiliations:- the All Nippon Kyudo Federation (ANKF) and the International Kyudo Federation (IKYF).

New Zealand Kyudo Federation

results.title: The Historical Society of Eastbourne Inc
results.description: The Historical Society of Eastbourne Inc. was originally established to promote an interest in local history.   Now has a large collection of historical information and photographs.
results.content: The Historical Society of Eastbourne Inc. was originally established to promote an interest in local history.   Now has a large collection of historical information and photographs.    Their rooms above the Eastbourne Library are open to the public every Monday afternoon from 2 - 4pm.  Staff will assist people with research.    Holds meetings with interesting speakers several times a year and provides a regular newsletter to members.  Welcomes new members.  Annual subscription is $10 single, $15.00 double.  The Society started the Eastbourne Heritage Trail which now has some 10 stands of notes and photos about local history around the town.
results.htmlcontent:
The Historical Society of Eastbourne Inc. was originally established to promote an interest in local history.   Now has a large collection of historical information and photographs.  

Their rooms above the Eastbourne Library are open to the public every Monday afternoon from 2 - 4pm.  Staff will assist people with research. 

Holds meetings with interesting speakers several times a year and provides a regular newsletter to members.  Welcomes new members.  Annual subscription is $10 single, $15.00 double.

The Society started the Eastbourne Heritage Trail which now has some 10 stands of notes and photos about local history around the town.

results.title: Wainuiomata Historical Museum Society Inc
results.description: The Wainuiomata Historical Society was established in 1977.  In March 1987 the Wellington Education Board gave the use of the ‘old school’, a 1908 heritage building, to the Society.  The Museum was opened on 30 September 1989 by Harry Martin, the first and only Mayor of Wainuiomata.
results.content: The Wainuiomata Historical Society was established in 1977.  In March 1987 the Wellington Education Board gave the use of the ‘old school’, a 1908 heritage building, to the Society.  The Museum was opened on 30 September 1989 by Harry Martin, the first and only Mayor of Wainuiomata.  The Museum is run by volunteers.  It aims to encourage the study of history and to foster public appreciation of local places and matters of historical interest. It does this by permanent preservation of a wide variety of objects and records and opening these to the public.  Welcomes helpers.  Opens on Sunday from 2-4pm and by arrangement other times for school groups and others.  Entry fee is a gold coin to help with the upkeep.
results.htmlcontent:
The Wainuiomata Historical Society was established in 1977.  In March 1987 the Wellington Education Board gave the use of the ‘old school’, a 1908 heritage building, to the Society.  The Museum was opened on 30 September 1989 by Harry Martin, the first and only Mayor of Wainuiomata.

The Museum is run by volunteers.  It aims to encourage the study of history and to foster public appreciation of local places and matters of historical interest. It does this by permanent preservation of a wide variety of objects and records and opening these to the public.  Welcomes helpers.

Opens on Sunday from 2-4pm and by arrangement other times for school groups and others.  Entry fee is a gold coin to help with the upkeep.

results.title: Arohanui Strings - Sistema Hutt Valley
results.description: Arohanui Strings - Sistema Hutt Valley is a registered charity that provides a music education and social development programme in the Hutt Valley and Wellington.  They take children, who might not otherwise have the opportunity to learn music, and help them to reach their potential through teamwork, harmony and ensemble playing.
results.content: Arohanui Strings - Sistema Hutt Valley is a registered charity that provides a music education and social development programme in the Hutt Valley and Wellington.  They take children, who might not otherwise have the opportunity to learn music, and help them to reach their potential through teamwork, harmony and ensemble playing.   Their mission is "to inspire children and youth to achieve their full potential, acquire values that favour their growth, and have a positive impact on both their lives and society".  Each child is given their own instrument and joins music classes held after school five days a week.  Some 200 children from the primary, intermediate and secondary schools in the area take part.  Children learn violin, viola, cello, double bass, singing and music literacy helped by teachers, student and parent helpers, and other volunteers.    The group gives concerts and runs free holiday music courses.  The programme is inspired by the Sistema model of teaching children music that was founded in Venezuela and is now widely used round the world.
results.htmlcontent:
Arohanui Strings - Sistema Hutt Valley is a registered charity that provides a music education and social development programme in the Hutt Valley and Wellington.  They take children, who might not otherwise have the opportunity to learn music, and help them to reach their potential through teamwork, harmony and ensemble playing. 

Their mission is "to inspire children and youth to achieve their full potential, acquire values that favour their growth, and have a positive impact on both their lives and society".

Each child is given their own instrument and joins music classes held after school five days a week.

Some 200 children from the primary, intermediate and secondary schools in the area take part.  Children learn violin, viola, cello, double bass, singing and music literacy helped by teachers, student and parent helpers, and other volunteers.  

The group gives concerts and runs free holiday music courses.

The programme is inspired by the Sistema model of teaching children music that was founded in Venezuela and is now widely used round the world.
results.physicalAddress:
Schools in Taita and Stokes Valley, Lower Hutt.
Mount Cook School in Wellington and Holy Cross School in Miramar.

results.title: Wellington Hindi School
results.description: Classes are held in three locations: 27 Kings Cres Lower Hutt on Sundays 10:00am -12.00pm Newlands address to be confirmed - Sundays 10.00am - 12.00pm 39 Webb St. Mt Cook, Wellington on  Sundays 10am -12.00pm
results.content: The school exists to provide language and culture service to anyone who wants to learn Hindi and the associated cultures.  Most of classes are running online.  The Wellington Hindi School’s award winning curriculum places learners and their families at the centre of the system. Their vision is to develop confident, connected, actively involved life-long learners who are integrated into the NZ community. They aspire to:  •       Deliver a holistic approach to teaching and learning of Hindi and cultural values. •       Use innovative approaches, including technology, to improve teaching and learning.  •       Align their Hindi programmes with the New Zealand school system.  •       Integrate learners into the New Zealand social, cultural and economic environment. •       Expose  students to experiences outside the Hindi classroom to develop overall competence and confidence.  •       Develop teacher and leadership capability through Professional Learning and Development opportunities. •       Collaborate with educators/Hindi schools/Hindi scholars in New Zealand and overseas to ensure that they are up to date with developments and trends.  Classes are held in three locations:  27 Kings Cres Lower Hutt on Sundays 10:00am -12.00pm Newlands address to be confirmed - Sundays 10.00am - 12.00pm 39 Webb St. Mt Cook, Wellington on  Sundays 10am -12.00pm
results.htmlcontent:
The school exists to provide language and culture service to anyone who wants to learn Hindi and the associated cultures.  Most of classes are running online.

The Wellington Hindi School’s award winning curriculum places learners and their families at the centre of the system. Their vision is to develop confident, connected, actively involved life-long learners who are integrated into the NZ community. They aspire to:

•       Deliver a holistic approach to teaching and learning of Hindi and cultural values.
•       Use innovative approaches, including technology, to improve teaching and learning.
•       Align their Hindi programmes with the New Zealand school system.
•       Integrate learners into the New Zealand social, cultural and economic environment.
•       Expose  students to experiences outside the Hindi classroom to develop overall competence and confidence.
•       Develop teacher and leadership capability through Professional Learning and Development opportunities.
•       Collaborate with educators/Hindi schools/Hindi scholars in New Zealand and overseas to ensure that they are up to date with developments and trends.

Classes are held in three locations:

  1. 27 Kings Cres Lower Hutt on Sundays 10:00am -12.00pm
  2. Newlands address to be confirmed - Sundays 10.00am - 12.00pm
  3. 39 Webb St. Mt Cook, Wellington on  Sundays 10am -12.00pm

results.title: Hutt Valley Orchestra
results.description: Hutt Valley Orchestra is a community orchestra of amateur players with a professional Conductor/Music Director, Mark Carter, who is the Sub Principal Trumpet with NZSO.
results.content: Hutt Valley Orchestra is a community orchestra of amateur players with a professional Conductor/Music Director, Mark Carter, who is the Sub Principal Trumpet with NZSO.  HVO plays a variety of music from the classical orchestra repertoire and also modern pieces. The main concert venue is St James Church in Woburn Road. Rehearsals are held on Monday evenings at St Marks Church in Woburn Road.  There are no auditions but at least Grade 5 is an indicator of the technical competence needed. Prospective members should email the orchestra if they are interested in joining and they will be in touch with further details and whether there are vacancies for their instrument.

results.title: Sisters of Compassion
results.description: St Joseph's Home of Compassion rest home and hospital in Heretaunga, Lower Hutt is a care facility for elderly people which also caters for people with dementia Compassion Housing in Upper Hutt and Levin provides houses for elderly people at a discounted rate. The sisters also run the Chanel Home of Compassion in Fiji for the elderly and those with disabilities.
results.content: The Sisters of Compassion, also known as the Daughters of Our Lady of Compassion, was founded by Suzanne Aubert at Jerusalem, Hiruhārama on the Whanganui River in 1892. For more than a century the sisters have taught, nursed, and provided homes for children, the sick and the elderly in New Zealand and the South Pacific. They are committed to delivering "compassionate care" throughout the community by providing meals, food, and basic needs to those who have very little, caring for the elderly, and providing individual and family support. They seek to bring dignity to the lives of the aged, the powerless and the poor. They have the following facilities:-  Our Lady's Home of Compassion, Island Bay, is our congregation's main office as well as being a conference and retreat centre.  A professional conference room seating 70 people lecture style and 30 people around tables, equipped with WiFi, audio/video and conference tables and chairs is available for half and full day meetings or workshops. Catering is available.          Accommodation sleeping 31 people, includes, single, double and twin share rooms with free breakfast, towels and WiFi.         It is also home to the Suzanne Aubert Heritage Centre which is free to visit. Coffee and simple homemade fare is available in the refreshment area. The centre is fully accessible. Onsite car parking available.  The Compassion Centre in Wellington includes the city's soup kitchen. St Joseph's Home of Compassion rest home and hospital in Heretaunga, Lower Hutt is a care facility for elderly people which also caters for people with dementia Compassion Housing in Upper Hutt and Levin provides houses for elderly people at a discounted rate. The sisters also run the Chanel Home of Compassion in Fiji for the elderly and those with disabilities.
results.htmlcontent:
The Sisters of Compassion, also known as the Daughters of Our Lady of Compassion, was founded by Suzanne Aubert at Jerusalem, Hiruhārama on the Whanganui River in 1892. For more than a century the sisters have taught, nursed, and provided homes for children, the sick and the elderly in New Zealand and the South Pacific. They are committed to delivering "compassionate care" throughout the community by providing meals, food, and basic needs to those who have very little, caring for the elderly, and providing individual and family support. They seek to bring dignity to the lives of the aged, the powerless and the poor. They have the following facilities:-

  • Our Lady's Home of Compassion, Island Bay, is our congregation's main office as well as being a conference and retreat centre.  A professional conference room seating 70 people lecture style and 30 people around tables, equipped with WiFi, audio/video and conference tables and chairs is available for half and full day meetings or workshops. Catering is available.

        Accommodation sleeping 31 people, includes, single, double and twin share rooms with free breakfast, towels and WiFi.

       It is also home to the Suzanne Aubert Heritage Centre which is free to visit. Coffee and simple homemade fare is available in the refreshment area. The centre is fully accessible. Onsite car parking available.

  • The Compassion Centre in Wellington includes the city's soup kitchen.
  • St Joseph's Home of Compassion rest home and hospital in Heretaunga, Lower Hutt is a care facility for elderly people which also caters for people with dementia
  • Compassion Housing in Upper Hutt and Levin provides houses for elderly people at a discounted rate.
  • The sisters also run the Chanel Home of Compassion in Fiji for the elderly and those with disabilities.

results.title: Sri Lanka Association of New Zealand (SLANZ) Inc
results.description: Sri Lanka Association of New Zealand (SLANZ) inc objectives are to foster, facilitate and promote within New Zealand, the development of cultural values and traditions of Sri Lanka, especially among the younger Sri Lankans. SLANZ is not a political organization. It complements the work of other Sri Lankan associations in the country, providing cultural and social support to the wider Sri Lankan Community.
results.content: Sri Lanka Association of New Zealand (SLANZ) inc objectives are to foster, facilitate and promote within New Zealand, the development of cultural values and traditions of Sri Lanka, especially among the younger Sri Lankans. SLANZ is not a political organization. It complements the work of other Sri Lankan associations in the country, providing cultural and social support to the wider Sri Lankan Community.  In conjunction with its AGM in (August/September) they hold an annual cultural night. Other activities during the year include conducting traditional Sri Lankan dancing workshops, voice training workshops, classes in guitar, violin, stage drama and Tabla. SLANZ also participates in the local Waitangai Day celebrations at Orongomai Marae  Intake process: Complete the online membership form here

results.title: Sri Lankan Dance Academy
results.description: Sri Lankan Dance Academy (SLDA) is a Wellington based charity which focuses on teaching traditional dance forms, and nurturing the modern dancing arts, of Sri Lanka. SLDA offers Sri Lankan children growing up in New Zealand, the chance to learn and experience their culture and heritage and to to provide an opportunity for the Wellingtonians to experience rich and colourful Sri Lankan culture.
results.content: Sri Lankan Dance Academy (SLDA) is a Wellington based charity which focuses on teaching traditional dance forms, and nurturing the modern dancing arts, of Sri Lanka. SLDA offers Sri Lankan children growing up in New Zealand, the chance to learn and experience their culture and heritage and to to provide an opportunity for the Wellingtonians to experience rich and colourful Sri Lankan culture.  They offer classes in: Sri Lankan Dancing Classes, Sri Lankan Drumming Classes, Aerobic and Fitness Classes, Productions, Group/Individual Performances (for class timetable check here) and hold an annual cricket tournament.

They offer classes in: Sri Lankan Dancing Classes, Sri Lankan Drumming Classes, Aerobic and Fitness Classes, Productions, Group/Individual Performances (for class timetable check here) and hold an annual cricket tournament.

results.title: Bodhinyanarama Buddhist Monastery
results.description: Bodhinyanarama, the Garden of Enlightened Knowing, was founded in 1983. It is a monastic residence of the Theravada tradition of Buddhism in Stokes Valley, near Wellington. Visitors are welcome. The stupa or pagoda is five minutes from the car park.
results.content: Bodhinyanarama, the Garden of Enlightened Knowing, was founded in 1983. It is a monastic residence of the Theravada tradition of Buddhism in Stokes Valley, near Wellington. Visitors are welcome. The stupa or pagoda is five minutes from the car park.  Its main purpose is as a residence for those taking part or training in the monastic lifestyle, but the large public area and meeting hall are also used for religious festivals, public meetings and retreats.  The forested area with remote lodgings provides an environment for seclusion. The senior monks instruct in meditation, teach Buddhist principles, lead retreats and provide religious services for the Buddhist community, both at the monastery and at other venues  The website gives details about contacting the Monastery and the various events visitors can attend. It is possible to stay at the Monastery.

results.title: I want to put up posters to advertise my gig. What are the rules for this?
results.description: The general rule is that you need to get permission from the owner of the property that you want to put the poster on.
results.content: The general rule is that you need to get permission from the owner of the property that you want to put the poster on.  For example, you will need to ask permission from:  the business owner (eg, a cafe) to put up a post on their wall or window; the owner of the shopping mall to put up a poster in their mall; the local council to put up posters on public property such as council buildings or other structures. Your council may have rules that differ depending on the size of poster and what it is promoting, In some situations where you want to put up a poster on private property, you may need to get permission from the council as well as permission from the property owner. This is likely to be necessary if the location is in an urban, suburban or rural centre.  To be sure, contact your local council first.
results.htmlcontent:
The general rule is that you need to get permission from the owner of the property that you want to put the poster on.

For example, you will need to ask permission from:

  • the business owner (eg, a cafe) to put up a post on their wall or window;
  • the owner of the shopping mall to put up a poster in their mall;
  • the local council to put up posters on public property such as council buildings or other structures. Your council may have rules that differ depending on the size of poster and what it is promoting,

In some situations where you want to put up a poster on private property, you may need to get permission from the council as well as permission from the property owner. This is likely to be necessary if the location is in an urban, suburban or rural centre.

To be sure, contact your local council first.

results.title: How do I find a book group or writers' group in my area?
results.description: Joining a book group can be a good way to ensure that you read books you might not otherwise read, and have the chance to discuss them with others. The Book Discussion Scheme website has a list of affiliated book groups. You can also try asking at your local public library.
results.content: Joining a book group can be a good way to ensure that you read books you might not otherwise read, and have the chance to discuss them with others. The Book Discussion Scheme website has a list of affiliated book groups. You can also try asking at your local public library.  If you want to start your own book group, you will find tips on the National Library website and the website of the publisher, Penguin.  If you are interested in writing, whether professionally or just as a hobby, getting together with other writers is a good way to get advice, feedback and inspiration. You can find a list of writers groups on the New Zealand Society of Authors website. Their website also includes advice for starting your own writers' group.  Your local CAB can also help you find a book club or writing group near you.
results.htmlcontent:
Joining a book group can be a good way to ensure that you read books you might not otherwise read, and have the chance to discuss them with others. The Book Discussion Scheme website has a list of affiliated book groups. You can also try asking at your local public library.

If you want to start your own book group, you will find tips on the National Library website and the website of the publisher, Penguin.

If you are interested in writing, whether professionally or just as a hobby, getting together with other writers is a good way to get advice, feedback and inspiration. You can find a list of writers groups on the New Zealand Society of Authors website. Their website also includes advice for starting your own writers' group.

Your local CAB can also help you find a book club or writing group near you.

results.title: What low cost leisure activities are available in my local area?
results.description: Most communities provide the public access to a range of leisure areas, facilities and activities either for free or at a low cost - the range and type will of course vary from place to place. They may include museums, art galleries, libraries, botanic gardens, nature walks, public swimming pools, fairs and festivals – and more besides.
results.content: Most communities provide the public access to a range of leisure areas, facilities and activities either for free or at a low cost - the range and type will of course vary from place to place. They may include museums, art galleries, libraries, botanic gardens, nature walks, public swimming pools, fairs and festivals – and more besides.   Most councils provide information about the leisure areas, facilities and activities available in their local area. Some of these activities are available at a discount for people with low income (eg, if you have a Community Services Card). Contact your local CAB to find out what is available in your area.

results.title: I am new to the area and want to link up with others with my cultural background. Is there a local group or organisation I can contact?
results.description: If you are new to New Zealand you might consider joining the New Zealand Newcomers Network, which has groups all over New Zealand. They hold social events and activities to suit all ages, cultures and religions.
results.content: If you are new to New Zealand you might consider joining the New Zealand Newcomers Network, which has groups all over New Zealand. They hold social events and activities to suit all ages, cultures and religions.  Your local CAB will be able to provide you with information and contact details for any groups or organisations there may be in your local area for your ethnic group or culture. Or, you can search our online community directory for this information.   You can also search the Office of Ethnic Communities’ online directory for ethnic community groups around New Zealand.

results.title: Two Todman Neighbours' Place
results.description: Opened in 2020 by Brooklyn Anglicans, Two Todman is a place for neighbours to gather. The building includes a Chapel for prayer and contemplation, a community space for local groups to use, and a second hand store and co-working space.
results.content: Opened in 2020 by Brooklyn Anglicans, Two Todman is a place for neighbours to gather. The building includes a Chapel for prayer and contemplation, a community space for local groups to use, and a second hand store and co-working space.   Co-Working Space - a shared space for local creatives, designers, non-profits and small business owners. This space includes kitchenette, lockable individual storage, bottomless filter coffee, and ultrafast broadband.  Day Hot Desk - $20+gst per day, pay as you go Monthly Hot Desk - $65+gst per week, $260+gst month term Monthly Fixed Desk - $85+gst per week, $340+gst month term Secondhand store - repurposes donated goods, also has a boutique shelf of local products and artists work. Profits are redistributed to community initiatives for the Brooklyn area. Funding which is distributes twice a year, is usually $500 - $2000.  For details of dates and an application form check the website.  Community Space for hire - A space available for hire by both community and commercial groups.  Non-profit rate - $15+gst per hour Commercial rate - $30+gst per hour Chapel - All people are welcome to use this as a set apart place of prayer, meditation and contemplation throughout the week. All are welcome to join in our regular rhythms.

results.title: SIAOLA - Vahefonua Tonga Methodist Mission Charitable Trust

results.title: Returned Services Association - Invercargill
results.description: The Invercargill Returned Services Association can now be contacted at the Invercargill Workingmen's Club. ANZAC Day ceremonies are held throughout Southland on 25 April each year. Armistice Day ceremonies are held at the Invercargill and Bluff Cenotaphs on 11 November each year.
results.content: The Invercargill Returned Services Association can now be contacted at the Invercargill Workingmen's Club. ANZAC Day ceremonies are held throughout Southland on 25 April each year. Armistice Day ceremonies are held at the Invercargill and Bluff Cenotaphs on 11 November each year.   Also administers the Patriotic Fund. The Invercargill RSA offers two scholarship grants to final year students attending a secondary school in Invercargill RSA district or it's Sub-Associations Districts. Applicants must intend studying at tertiary level in the following year. Each scholarship is to the value of $1,000.00 and preference will be given to an applicant who is a direct descendant of an ex-serviceman/woman. Applications close mid December.

results.title: Wellington City Libraries
results.description: Eleven suburban libraries operate in Wellington.
results.content: Eleven suburban libraries operate in Wellington.  The main library in Wellington City has been closed because of earthquake risk and pop-up library services are operating for inner city residents and workers. Currently they are:-  Arapaki Manners Library He Matapihi Molesworth Library Te Awe Library   Internet (free for 60 minutes), free Wifi, printing and faxing facilities are available at all libraries. Services and activities are similar throughout.  Some popular library services are:-  Kids activities:- Baby Rock & Rhyme, preschool story times, holiday activities and book clubs  Migrant information: The library has material to help people learn English, and a growing collection of books, newspapers and DVDs in other languages. People can request an interpreter when visiting the Library. Some libraries have social English Groups. Prosearch:- Research services for businesses and individuals. This services is useful for people wanting to start a new business. Their Business Information Specialist offer business research which access demographic and promotion information for business ideas. They also offer one hour free, one on one training to people wanting to access this information for themselves. Library services for people with disability:- These include housebound services for permanently disabled, talking books, library express, cassettes, CDs, DVDs and videos, large print, audio visual material, talking books. Books are delivered to the closest library to the client, then delivered by volunteers.  Eligibility: Wellington Residents
results.htmlcontent:
Eleven suburban libraries operate in Wellington.

The main library in Wellington City has been closed because of earthquake risk and pop-up library services are operating for inner city residents and workers. Currently they are:-

  1. Arapaki Manners Library
  2. He Matapihi Molesworth Library
  3. Te Awe Library 

Internet (free for 60 minutes), free Wifi, printing and faxing facilities are available at all libraries. Services and activities are similar throughout.


Some popular library services are:-

  • Kids activities:- Baby Rock & Rhyme, preschool story times, holiday activities and book clubs 
  • Migrant information: The library has material to help people learn English, and a growing collection of books, newspapers and DVDs in other languages. People can request an interpreter when visiting the Library. Some libraries have social English Groups.
  • Prosearch:- Research services for businesses and individuals. This services is useful for people wanting to start a new business. Their Business Information Specialist offer business research which access demographic and promotion information for business ideas. They also offer one hour free, one on one training to people wanting to access this information for themselves.
  • Library services for people with disability:- These include housebound services for permanently disabled, talking books, library express, cassettes, CDs, DVDs and videos, large print, audio visual material, talking books. Books are delivered to the closest library to the client, then delivered by volunteers.

Eligibility:
Wellington Residents
results.openingHours: Opening hours vary for each library.

results.title: Mid Canterbury Country Music Club
results.description: People of all ages are welcome to come along for an afternoon of country music with a live band. You can sing, with members having first priority, or just enjoy an afternoon of entertainment. No experience is required and there are members who are happy to help guide you. The club provides a band, sound, microphones, etc. but you are more than welcome to bring along your own instrument.
results.content: People of all ages are welcome to come along for an afternoon of country music with a live band. You can sing, with members having first priority, or just enjoy an afternoon of entertainment. No experience is required and there are members who are happy to help guide you. The club provides a band, sound, microphones, etc. but you are more than welcome to bring along your own instrument.  You could even learn a new skill like operating the sound desk or how to set up/pack down the musical equipment.  As well as regular club days they also try to organise a variety of events throughout the year for members to enjoy. In previous years this has included subsidised bus trips and meals, shared lunches, picnics, and performances at local events such as Plains Railway Museum Christmas Celebration.  Membership is not required to attend club days, however new members are welcome. Feel free to come along to the next club day (Usually advertised in the Ashburton Courier).  Members receive regular newsletters, special events, and an invitation to the AGM & Christmas celebration every December.  Fees  Membership is $20 per person, or $35 per family (within the same household).  Raffles are available for purchase on the day ($2 a ticket). Food and beverage available for purchase from the bar and/or restaurant.

results.title: Omaka Observatory Trust
results.description: An outdoor crater observatory in the Omaka Valley. Venue has been created to help generations to come to appreciate the dark sky on our door step.
results.content: An outdoor crater observatory in the Omaka Valley. Venue has been created to help generations to come to appreciate the dark sky on our door step.  Free access will be offered to school groups, whist also running a tourism stargazing business. A standard tours of one hour is limited to a maximum of 18 people. Tickets can be purchased online or through the Picton and Blenheim i sites.  There is no private transport permitted to the site. Their bus picks patrons from the Blenheim Railway Station (opposite the i-site) with a second pick up point at the Runway Cafe on Middle Renwick Road.  The Trust also operates an Astronomy club which holds meetings on the first Monday of every month in Marlborough. These meetings will include the opportunity to meet others, listen to talks and use a range of telescopes.

Free access will be offered to school groups, whist also running a tourism stargazing business. A standard tours of one hour is limited to a maximum of 18 people. Tickets can be purchased online or through the Picton and Blenheim i sites.

There is no private transport permitted to the site. Their bus picks patrons from the Blenheim Railway Station (opposite the i-site) with a second pick up point at the Runway Cafe on Middle Renwick Road.

The Trust also operates an Astronomy club which holds meetings on the first Monday of every month in Marlborough. These meetings will include the opportunity to meet others, listen to talks and use a range of telescopes.

results.title: Te Ngākau Kahukura
results.description: Te Ngākau Kahukura is a national initiative developed in partnership with rainbow communities to make communities, environments and systems more safe and inclusive. They aim to create system change by lobbying funders, decision makers, training providers and sector bodies that provide health and social services.
results.content: Te Ngākau Kahukura is a national initiative developed in partnership with rainbow communities to make communities, environments and systems more safe and inclusive. They aim to create system change by lobbying funders, decision makers, training providers and sector bodies that provide health and social services.  They work collaboratively with professionals, organisations and wider systems that support people across Aotearoa, including health, housing, social, education and justice to support and be more inclusive of rainbow people.  They help rainbow community organisations to build their capacity and connections but do not provide services directly to individuals themselves.  Contact via website form www.tengakaukahukura.nz/need-more  Te Ngākau Kahukura within the organisational structure of Ara Taiohi.
results.htmlcontent:

results.title: Paeroa - Historical Maritime Park Inc
results.description: A local museum, run by volunteers, based in Paeroa within a garden/park setting beside the river. The museum is  home to a collection of Maritime history relating to the role that Paeroa played as a port for unloading mining machinery and equipment in the late 19th century.
results.content: A local museum, run by volunteers, based in Paeroa within a garden/park setting beside the river. The museum is  home to a collection of Maritime history relating to the role that Paeroa played as a port for unloading mining machinery and equipment in the late 19th century.    There is a cycle link to/from Hauraki Rail Trail. Self contained camper vans can stay over night on the park grounds for $20/night (plus $5 if power required)  River cruises - 3 different vessels including a paddle boat (the Tamati) are available for cruising the Ohinemuri and Waihou Rivers.  The venue is available for hire and with the river view, park grounds and gardens would be suitable for weddings and private functions wanting to make the most of the indoor and outdoor setting.  Each year in December a Christmas Light show is held in the park.  This is a ticketed event which raises funds for the upkeep of the park.  Entry fees to the museum and grounds apply - Family (2 adults, 2 children) - $20
results.htmlcontent:
A local museum, run by volunteers, based in Paeroa within a garden/park setting beside the river. The museum is  home to a collection of Maritime history relating to the role that Paeroa played as a port for unloading mining machinery and equipment in the late 19th century.  

There is a cycle link to/from Hauraki Rail Trail. Self contained camper vans can stay over night on the park grounds for $20/night (plus $5 if power required)

River cruises - 3 different vessels including a paddle boat (the Tamati) are available for cruising the Ohinemuri and Waihou Rivers.

The venue is available for hire and with the river view, park grounds and gardens would be suitable for weddings and private functions wanting to make the most of the indoor and outdoor setting.

Each year in December a Christmas Light show is held in the park.  This is a ticketed event which raises funds for the upkeep of the park.

Entry fees to the museum and grounds apply - Family (2 adults, 2 children) - $20

results.title: Buller District Library
results.description: The Library provides public library services at two main locations in Buller, the district library in Westport (Sue Thomson Casey Memorial Library) and a branch library in Reefton (Inangahua County Library).  Membership provides access to the collections at both libraries as well as the digital and audio collections.  Library and information services to the community include:
results.content: The Library provides public library services at two main locations in Buller, the district library in Westport (Sue Thomson Casey Memorial Library) and a branch library in Reefton (Inangahua County Library).  Membership provides access to the collections at both libraries as well as the digital and audio collections.  Library and information services to the community include:  Free internet and computing (6 computers at Westport and 3 at Reefton) Printing (charges apply) Assistance with RealMe and MyAccount in collaboration with Work and income. Stepping UP computer classes – free computer & internet training Better Digital Futures for Seniors classes for people aged 65+ to learn new skills and build confidence with computers and the internet. Assistance to apply for Skinny Jump – prepay home broadband with no contract, no credit checks and no set-up charges. Membership of the libraries is free for all ratepayers and permanent residents of Buller District.
results.htmlcontent:
The Library provides public library services at two main locations in Buller, the district library in Westport (Sue Thomson Casey Memorial Library) and a branch library in Reefton (Inangahua County Library).  Membership provides access to the collections at both libraries as well as the digital and audio collections.  Library and information services to the community include:

  • Free internet and computing (6 computers at Westport and 3 at Reefton)
  • Printing (charges apply)
  • Assistance with RealMe and MyAccount in collaboration with Work and income.
  • Stepping UP computer classes – free computer & internet training
  • Better Digital Futures for Seniors classes for people aged 65+ to learn new skills and build confidence with computers and the internet.
  • Assistance to apply for Skinny Jump – prepay home broadband with no contract, no credit checks and no set-up charges.

Membership of the libraries is free for all ratepayers and permanent residents of Buller District.

results.title: No.24 (Ashburton) Squadron Air Training Corps
results.description: Cadet Units offer a wide variety of training and experiences that are unique to the Cadet Force, and teach life and work skills that open up new possibilities, opportunities and career options. Cadets learn to be part of a team, develop leadership and survival skills, make new friends, experience challenges and learn to take responsibility.
results.content: Cadet Units offer a wide variety of training and experiences that are unique to the Cadet Force, and teach life and work skills that open up new possibilities, opportunities and career options. Cadets learn to be part of a team, develop leadership and survival skills, make new friends, experience challenges and learn to take responsibility.  Air Cadet Units hold activities throughout the year, including outdoor and adventure training such as:  Parade Nights - Every unit holds Parade Nights weekly, approximately 3–4 hours per night during the school terms. Powered Flying and Gliding- Air Cadet Units typically organise practical Flying or Gliding Training for the cadets in partnership with local Aero Clubs. Aviation Syllabus - Cadets will learn aviation history, how engines work, aircraft technology, air navigation, air field layout, weather maps, aviation radio and more. Bushcraft - Air Cadet Units give their cadets the opportunity to become skilled and comfortable in the bush environment. Theory lessons and scenarios are supported with camps run throughout the year, each providing new and exciting activities and skills. Firearms Safety and Marksmanship Training - Units conduct regular firearms safety and shooting skills training. Duke of Edinburgh - All training provided by the NZCF can be cross-credited to those who are working towards their Duke of Edinburgh’s Hillary Award. The Air Training Corps (ATC), commonly known as Air Cadets, is the arm of the New Zealand Cadet Forces (NZCF) aligned with the Royal New Zealand Air Force (RNZAF)  Eligibility :13–15-year-olds are welcome to apply.
results.htmlcontent:
Cadet Units offer a wide variety of training and experiences that are unique to the Cadet Force, and teach life and work skills that open up new possibilities, opportunities and career options. Cadets learn to be part of a team, develop leadership and survival skills, make new friends, experience challenges and learn to take responsibility.

Air Cadet Units hold activities throughout the year, including outdoor and adventure training such as:

  • Parade Nights - Every unit holds Parade Nights weekly, approximately 3–4 hours per night during the school terms.
  • Powered Flying and Gliding- Air Cadet Units typically organise practical Flying or Gliding Training for the cadets in partnership with local Aero Clubs.
  • Aviation Syllabus - Cadets will learn aviation history, how engines work, aircraft technology, air navigation, air field layout, weather maps, aviation radio and more.
  • Bushcraft - Air Cadet Units give their cadets the opportunity to become skilled and comfortable in the bush environment. Theory lessons and scenarios are supported with camps run throughout the year, each providing new and exciting activities and skills.
  • Firearms Safety and Marksmanship Training - Units conduct regular firearms safety and shooting skills training.
  • Duke of Edinburgh - All training provided by the NZCF can be cross-credited to those who are working towards their Duke of Edinburgh’s Hillary Award.

The Air Training Corps (ATC), commonly known as Air Cadets, is the arm of the New Zealand Cadet Forces (NZCF) aligned with the Royal New Zealand Air Force (RNZAF)

Eligibility :13–15-year-olds are welcome to apply.
